text: yup I was more questioning the correct typing convention to use, i.e. the Type[] part

text: not 100% but I think you just name the class you want in general. You need extra semantics for optional types

elements.text: not 100% but I think you just name the class you want in general. You need extra semantics for optional types

text: eg: def f(input : baseResource) -> None:

elements.text: eg: def f(input : baseResource) -> None:

text: Type[obj] is for referencing the actual _class_ not an _instance._ So is used for methods/functions that will act on classes themselves (eg. a function that works by calling `___init___` on the class passed in the arguments, then returning a new instance)

elements.text: Type[obj] is for referencing the actual
class
not an
instance.
So is used for methods/functions that will act on classes themselves (eg. a function that works by calling
init__
on the class passed in the arguments, then returning a new instance)

Have any of you guys ever thought to yourselves, why I am I working so hard to make such small (if any) profits in an ever shrinking and saturated market that is almost entirely dependent on a single monolithic entity that is free to raise their charges at any stage, ensuring they are the only ones that will be left winning in the end?

elements.text: Have any of you guys ever thought to yourselves, why I am I working so hard to make such small (if any) profits in an ever shrinking and saturated market that is almost entirely dependent on a single monolithic entity that is free to raise their charges at any stage, ensuring they are the only ones that will be left winning in the end?

text: Not exactly because I don't consider my profits small and I don't think liquidity or competition are big problems for me but the existential threat of being completely dependent on Betfair does keep me up at night

elements.text: Not exactly because I don't consider my profits small and I don't think liquidity or competition are big problems for me but the existential threat of being completely dependent on Betfair does keep me up at night

text: One of my big worries other then being dependant on Betfair (which I hope will see a competitor if they slack too much) is their blase attitude / disregard  for very uncommon situations and are happy to throw people under the bus and hide behind T&Cs, saying ah it wont happen again. In some of these situations is impossible to protect yourself as a user of the platform acting in good faith other then imposing exposure limits. Prime example was a few weeks back when the wrong horse ran in a race and won the race. The whole market operated like it was the correct horse. I dont think people really understood the implications of this (and probably still dont as it didn't effect them this time). A response like yeh but its so rare isnt good enough in my opinion. Will they even settle the market the same next time when its their money thats been shafted?

text:
One thing I learned from losing a lot -- if a couple of mistakes (regardless of the sources) could significantly ruin your P/L -- then it's probably not a good system.  These days I am spending most of my time backtesting and compiling all the worst possible outcome that I came across in my testing/live and whatever strat I come up with must be able to survive those.

Of course,  past data is no indicator of future performance but how could one say a system is working if it could not even do well when backtested? :sweat_smile:

elements.text:
One thing I learned from losing a lot -- if a couple of mistakes (regardless of the sources) could significantly ruin your P/L -- then it's probably not a good system.  These days I am spending most of my time backtesting and compiling all the worst possible outcome that I came across in my testing/live and whatever strat I come up with must be able to survive those.

Of course,  past data is no indicator of future performance but how could one say a system is working if it could not even do well when backtested?
